sen.j: 買米令（かわせまいれい）は、1730年（享保16年）に、享保の改革の一環として行われた法令。
sen.e: In 1730, the Kawase-mai-rei Law was enforced as part of the Kyoho Reforms (the reforms made in the Kyoho era of the Edo period).
In 1730, the Kawase-mai-rei Law was enforced as part of the Kyoho Reforms (the reforms made in the Kyoho era of the Edo period).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: In 1730, the Kawase-mai-rei Law was enforced as part of the Kyoho Reforms (the reforms made in the Kyoho era of the Edo period).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 江戸幕府が市場の米を買い上げ貯蔵して米価の引き上げを促すとともに、諸藩や江戸・大坂の有力商人達にも強制的に同様の措置を行わせた。
sen.e: The Edo Shognate purchased rice of the market to stock, while forcing the Domains and influential merchants in Edo and Osaka to undertake a similar measure to raise the rice price.
The Edo Shogunate purchased rice from the market and stored it away to regulate rice prices, and required all the domains and influential merchants in Edo and Osaka to do the same..
sen.cmt: 意味をよりわかりやすくするために変えました。
sen.e: The Edo Shogunate purchased rice from the market and stored it away to regulate rice prices, and required all the domains and influential merchants in Edo and Osaka to do the same..
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: なお、公式文書などでは、幕府が直接行う買い上げは「かいまい」、商人達に強制的に行わせるものは「かわせまい」と呼称させて区別されている。
sen.e: In the official documents, purchasing rice by the government was referred to as 'Kai-mai' and forcing merchants to buy rice was referred as 'Kawase-mai' to distinguish from each other.
In the official documents, when the government purchased rice it was referred to as 'Kai-mai', while rice purchases by merchants was referred as 'Kawase-mai'.
sen.cmt: 意味をよりわかりやすくするために変えました。
sen.e: In the official documents, when the government purchased rice it was referred to as 'Kai-mai', while rice purchases by merchants was referred as 'Kawase-mai'.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これによって市場に流通する米の量を減らして米価を強制的に引き上げさせ、米価の低落によって年貢収入の換金に支障を来たしていた武士階層を救済することを図った。
sen.e: This law was intended to decrease the rice distribution at the market, forcibly increasing the rice price to bail out samurai class who had had a problem in converting the tax, which was paid in rice, into cash due to the law rice price.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The intent of this law was to raise the price of rice by decreasing the amount on the market, which would help the samurai class who had a problem converting their yearly income into cash if the price of rice was low.
sen.cmt: 意味をよりわかりやすくするために変えました。
sen.e: The intent of this law was to raise the price of rice by decreasing the amount on the market, which would help the samurai class who had a problem converting their yearly income into cash if the price of rice was low.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ともに、彼らの購買力を高めて景気回復を図った。
sen.e: Then, the economic recovery was expected by enhancing their purchasing power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: By increasing their purchasing power they hoped to strengthen the economy.
sen.cmt: 意味をよりわかりやすくするために変えました。
sen.e: By increasing their purchasing power they hoped to strengthen the economy.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、同様の目的で米切手の為替化容認（結果的に米の延べ売買となり、米の売出しの先送りとなる）、囲米奨励、諸藩に対する江戸・大坂への廻米・蔵屋敷の米売却の制限・禁止などの措置が取られている。
sen.e: For the same purpose, the government admitted to use kome-kitte (rice voucher) as money order (this resulted in a post-dated transaction, a futures market of rice), encouraged to stockpile the rice, and controlled or restricted the Domains transporting the rice and the Kurayashiki (Warehouse-residence) selling the rice.
sen.cmt: 前項まで、江戸幕府が主語になっているので、「the government」を補って能動態にしました。
sen.e: For the same purpose the government allowed kome-kitte (rice voucher) to be used as money orders (this resulted in a pre-date transactions of rice), encouraged the stockpiling of rice, and controlled or restricted the domains transporting the rice, and the Kurayashiki (Warehouse-residences) from selling the rice.
sen.cmt: 前項まで、江戸幕府が主語になっているので、「the government」を補って能動態にしました。
sen.e: For the same purpose the government allowed kome-kitte (rice voucher) to be used as money orders (this resulted in a pre-date transactions of rice), encouraged the stockpiling of rice, and controlled or restricted the domains transporting the rice, and the Kurayashiki (Warehouse-residences) from selling the rice.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 以後、延享元年、宝暦11年、文化_(元号)7年などにも同様の法令が出されている。
sen.e: Then, in 1744, 1761, and 1812, similar laws were enforced.
Similar laws were enforced in 1744, 1761, and 1812.
sen.cmt: 意味をよりわかりやすくするために変えました。
sen.e: Similar laws were enforced in 1744, 1761, and 1812.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 大坂においては、幕府の金庫同然であったから、享保以来、買米を命じられたことは10余度に及んだ。
sen.e: In Osaka, the Kurayashiki was similar to a cashbox for the government, they were ordered to buy rice over 10 times since Kyoho era.
sen.cmt: ここの文章では「何が」幕府の金庫同様だか載っていないのですが、主語がないと訳せないため蔵屋敷と解釈しました。

sen.j: ただし、大坂ばかりでなく江戸、京都、堺その他にも賦課されたが、買米高では大阪が群を抜いていた。
sen.e: Not only Osaka, but also Edo, Kyoto, Sakai and other cities were also imposed the tax, but Osaka purchased the largest amount of rice.
